commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Wear on earth?  (5)
2. Shops for a short time?  (3)-(2) (6)
3. Found a parking spot  (3)
4. Layer of gold?  (5)
5. Deer stalking aid?  (5)(7)

ERODE
POP-UP STORES
SAT
GOOSE
SANTA TRACKER

Said the watch to the clock, "You tockin' to me?"

(The clock was ticked.)
Fun, breezy puzzle with an enjoyably innocent theme!
Good golly, Miss Molly! That was an easy one.

I enjoyed this collaboration from Andrea and Dena. 

That’s a fact, Jack.

@Whoa Nellie,

You’re in the Crossword today!!!
I actually found this to be a little tricky for a Monday.

Jeepers creepers, that was quick and a lot of fun.  

Congratulations on your debut-for-two, and thank you for this neat puzzle.

I enjoyed the puzzle.

However, I am *completely* stumped by BYEFELICIA.  

What's the origin, smart people?
A little slower than the average Monday, but the clever theme was totally worth it.

I knew it!  Constructors are mining the Wordplay comments for content!  Sunday we had SLOG and the clue, "Obscure." Monday we have SLOG again but also WHOA NELLY, the name of one of our solvers, and GEEZ LOUISE, from a comment made by @HeathieJ on the Sunday puzzle just hours ago. These constructors are certainly speedy to be able to put together a whole puzzle so quickly. But don't you think we should get a percentage of the ginormous fee from the NYT? We'll be rich!!!

Fun puzzle and I have no serious complaints. But I gotta know, who actually says “holy camoly!”?
I thought maybe I’d made a mondegreen with Holy Cannoli, the term I’ve used for years. So I googled camoly and got a few hits but not nearly as many as my phrasing of choice. I guess it’s working its way into usage but I’m still going to, ahem, take the cannoli.
A good one. Faster than my average Monday. Enjoyed it lots. Thanks!

🤔

"Y."

"Y?"

NOWAYJOSE!

I wasn't aware that Hemingway had "Papa" as a nickname, but I have heard "Papa Haydn." There's even a little children's song, to the tune of the Surprise Symphony (mvt.2). 

Papa Haydn's dead and gone,
But his memory lingers on.
When his tune was one of bliss
He wrote jolly tunes like this.
Very enjoyable even if it took me "too" long to finish. As far as I'm concerned any Xword puzzle with NENE is my favorite. I nearly lost it when I first went to HI and saw one! Bravo!
Tried to fit Phrygian into 66 across but it wouldn’t fit.  C’est la vie. Anyway, a very enjoyable puzzle.  Really fun.  Thank you for a nice solve.

Very smooth start to the week.

A Monday collaboration so nice that it gets a pass on OREO number 502, the eighth cookie served up in 2025.

Congratulations, Dena R. Verkuil on your NYT debut, and hats off to Andrea Carla Michaels for sharing your love of crosswording with other constructors (and solvers!)

Thinking back on my impressions of Taxi Driver, which I saw when it came out, but not since, is how perfect Robert DeNiro was, and how dirty and gritty NY was and all the characters who toiled in it, turning into animals, soulless and amoral ones, schooled in the arts of survival.  Like that sordid scene when Travis Bickle takes Betsy (young Cybill Shepherd) to a movie, some weird x-rated grainy film with Wilhelm Reich's involvement -- watching it, I felt the molasses ooze of NY inching up my pantleg and into my system... well anyway, great movie, but never wanted to see it again. 

Much more comfortable when De Niro plays a CAPO, which he's done several times, like in that long beauty from Scorcese, The Irishman (2019). 

And here I was thinking "Bye Felicia" was from the doo-wop era, like "Goodnight, Irene." Or Wake Up, Little Susie. Or couldn't you see Elvis singing it? B-b-b-b-b-b-b-bye-bye bye Felicia, bye bye bye bye bye bye Felicia...
NELLIE, I always thought.
Favorite line from a movie? “You’re gonna need a bigger boat.”
I really loved the phrases in this one. 5:02 might be my new Monday record!

I actually saw the movie "Friday" when it first came out, remember the line "bye, Felisha", but never knew it was a common thing. 
My favorite line from that movie is still "don't nobody go in the bathroom for about 35, 45 minutes"

A very enjoyable puzzle - Monday-easy but satisfying to solve 👍🏾

I've never seen "Taxi Driver" 🤣. I know the line, however, because it featured in Poland's most liked 1990s comedy, "Killer", about a nice Polish guy who gets mistaken for a world-class assassin, and tries to imitate movie tough guys before his mirror to get into character.

I got the theme. I didn't understand how the revealer was supposed to work, though. I needed the column to explain that to me 🤣

The themed entries were easy to get. I stumbled on the last one for a minute. I thought all the names would be female, and I momentarily forgot She-ra was a Princess of Power. I wanted NO WAY JANE there 😃. aH YES worked. nHERA looked very weird though, so I gave the entries there another look and suddenly remembered both the expression NO WAY JOSE and the name SHE-RA. D'oh!

Btw, is it me or is the satisfied sound randomly (arbitrarily?) spelled either AHH or AaH?

Speaking of SHE-RA, in a way: He-man was one of the few Western shows on Polish TV in the 1980s. I was 7-ish at the time but already spoke basic English. I was so puzzled by that name: why the double indication of masculinity? Isn't that a bit weird? The realization may have been a prelude to my deep dislike for overblown, toxic masculinity in my middle age.

As for my favorite movie lines, they are all from "Seksmisja" by Juliusz Machulski and "Miś" by Stanisław Bareja (Polish comedies from the 1980s), so quoting them here would be no use.
This puzzle was smart, witty and so much fun. More from these puzzle makers please!
I have tried thrice now to leave a comment with favorite movie lines but the comment board keeps shutting down on me.  Bye Felicia!
Probably would have had my all time PB if I hadn’t started out with PICK in 1A instead of CAPO. That and all the typos.

“You do an eclectic celebration of the dance! You do Fosse, Fosse, Fosse! You do Martha Graham, Martha Graham, Martha Graham! Or Twyla, Twyla, Twyla! Or Michael Kidd, Michael Kidd, Michael Kidd, Michael Kidd! Or Madonna, Madonna, Madonna!... but you keep it all inside.” 
Armand (Robin Williams), The Birdcage

“A martini. Shaken, not stirred.”
James Bond (Sean Connery), Goldfinger
27A, alternatively, "You need to borrow a ___!" Perhaps that's a more Friday level clue for it though.

Leaving my constructor notes here, since I didn’t get them in on time to Sam, due to time differences mixed with a heavy dose of jet lag:

I have been solving crossword puzzles constructed by the inimitable Andrea Carla Michaels since I was a kid (first in the TV Guide and eventually graduating to the NYT) but we did not meet until 2023 at which time we became fast friends. Collaborating with Andrea is a quick way to learn how to construct a classic Monday puzzle like this one. Hope you enjoy!
Fun Monday puzzle and delightful constructor notes as one must expect from Andrea.

A good puzzle, but...........
25d cashmere or angora has an impossible answer!  The only animal that produces wool is a sheep.  All other animal fibres produce YARN.  All wool is yarn, but not all yarn is wool.  A rookie error which slowed down the solve for me, both being 4 letter words!
@Sam, first line to hit me was "... we're not in Kansas anymore".

Your resident curmudgeon weighing in. Even Rex Parker liked this puzzle.

Definitely not my kind of puzzle, though it certainly was easy, thanks to the crossings. BYE, FELICIA? HOLY CAMOLY? Guess as usual I'm the odd woman out.

“As you wish….!”

A personal best this Monday morning and, like others had a few wait and see moments including pick for CAPO and yarn for WOOL. No google searches required. Thanks for a fun start to vacation week. Bye, Felicia!
Great collection of phrases and a fun revealer! I'd never heard "holy camoly", just "holy cannoli".  And always thought it was NELLie, not NELLY. But otherwise, loved this one.
I wish we could retire, "Bye, Felicia."

To our constructors:
Bless you both, for this fine Monday offering.

(Who an Elly? You an Elly!)

Easy peasy. Quick solve with a clever theme. I thought the line was, "You lookin' at me?"
No doubt there's a tough Strands in the queue.

Sweet whimsical theme.  Quirky charming phrases tied together by an iconic movie phrase – “You talkin’ to me?” – that evokes a mood that’s fun to feel.

I love the rhyme of the LOUISE and JOSE phrases.

Lots of lovely serendipities in the box today:
•	Food references: OREO, NUTS, FED, EATEN, ASADA, FETA, FAVA.
•	Speaking of FAVA, row 12 – GRIN / AHH / FAVA – Reminds me of “Silence of the Lambs”.
•	PuzzPair© of STYE and MUST ACHE.
•	Sea jargon cross of AYE and AHOY.
•	Boggle-style TED neighboring LASSO.

Congratulations, Debut Dena, and to you, Andrea, on your 88th Times puzzle.  Your puzzle left me in a splendid mood -- thank you!

Fun puzzle.  Many thanks. 

I once had a baseball glove just like the one in the picture.  Probably has turned to dust by now. 

I totally DOOK'd myself in the Mini.  What the heck is "I'm in d"??  GEEZLOUISE indeed.
I was today years old when I found out that it’s not Holy Cannoli. Fun puzzle- nice work!

Fun Monday puzzle and a nice workout for me. Always glad to see an ACME enterprise and nice to see another new constructor. Looking forward to more from Ms. Verkuil. The reveal dawned on me fairly early and just needed some crosses to get each of the theme answers. Appropriate puzzle find today, inspired by GEEZLOUISE, which only appeared in one other puzzle - a Tuesday from April 6, 2021 by Amanda Chung and Karl Ni. Other theme answers in that one: HEAVENSTOBETSY and a pair of synchronous down answers; GOODGOLLY MISSMOLLY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/6/2021&g=23&d=A ...
A rare editorial error today. It should be "Woah, Nellie!" ;-)

I normally save the crossword for later in the day, but last night I had a dream that I'd lost my 313-day streak (now 314!) because I forgot to do today's puzzle. I was particularly frustrated (in the dream) because Monday puzzles take so little time!

I thought (still in the dream) that although it was frustrating to have to start my streak over, at least I hadn't lost my Peloton streak (which will be 1895 days after I've done today's workout) or my Duolingo streak (which will be 3501 days after I do some lessons later today).

 I would have had a Monday PR today, but it took about thirty seconds for me to go through the puzzle (after not getting the happy music) and realize I had aHYES instead of OHYES. 🤦‍♀️

Straightforward today, mainly because of what I've learned or used in previous crosswords!
Obviously OREO, ALES (I'd always say beer, ale sounds pretentious), SSN, LYES (never used), FAVA (broad beans) and ASTRO.

I'm only familiar with the No way José phrase from many years ago, and haven't heard it for years, and the others - never actually heard. Online suggestions for UK 
Geez Louise:  Crikey! Blimey!
For Woah Nelly: Hold your horses
For Holy camoly: Bloody hell
For Bye Felicia: No equivalent and I had to look up for the meaning. 

OREOS are available but I'd never noticed them before NYTX.

Lovely Monday.
WHOANELLY! Somebody's gotta do a puzzle with this as a name game theme!
"Bye, Felicia?" Is that a thing?
the ear worms! Shirley https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l7izuF4oN4c Jack https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uSiHqxgE2d0

My only takeaway from today's puzzle is how it largely contains a myriad of essential “filler” words every beginner solver needs to know. I tip my Phrygian hat to the constructor.

Icing on the cake to this whimsical theme would have been a reference to a Vintage TV spot for JGE Appliances: "What's the story, Jerry?" That's just me, though. You New Yorkers get it.

“Carping” was very clever, only solvable by the crosses for me. Very nice! “Hands out hands” and sea si’… equally clever.

Thank you for your charming puzzle, Dena and Andrea.

As for Sam's question, M Biggen already posted one of my faves, but here are two from just one guy, Pacino.

Attica! Attica!
-Dog Day Afternoon 

Just when I thought I was out, they pull me back in.
-Godfather 3

And one from Dustin Hoffman 
I'm walkin here!
-Midnight Cowboy
Sometimes quick ones are fun too. 4m53s today but enjoyable.

Well that was fun. None of the lines are in common use over here, but 61A was the only I’ve never come across at all. @Jane Wheelaghan came up with some potential British alternatives; I’ve added my imagined take on the above. In general I believe we Brits use much more colourful language for slang/insults. I blame the Vikings!

Favourite line/one used most often in our family; ‘One does not simply walk into Mordor’ (/my bedroom/the kitchen/the barn/the pub etc etc).
What can I say. I’ve proudly raised a family of LOTR nerds.
What happened to "Heavens to Betsy"?

Instead of a real comment, I added comments on other comments...

Belatedly, it came to me that our family 'borrowed' (more like 'confiscated') "We don't need no stinkin' badges!"... with the [whatever] we don't need/have forgotten/lost inserted in place of the badges. 

In other news, we attended the Vicksburg Symphonic Society concert yesterday; (PhysicsDaughter plays the viola.)  All the standard patriotic songs (plus, of course, the national anthem) were on the program.  When "God Bless America" began, the entire audience jumped to their feet...(we  were belated and slightly bewildered.  When did this become A Thing?)  

Nit to pick:  the Army Artillery ballad has been conscripted, and instead of "the caissons go rolling along," it's the entire Army that goes rollin'.....  Nothing is sacred anymore.
Never heard of BYE FELICIA.  Needed to solve with crosses.
"Is this your homework Larry?"

Strands #484 “Trellis beauties” 🔵🔵🔵🟡 🔵🔵 Don't comment here. The new Strands column Sidekick is at https://www.nytimes.com/2025/06/29/crosswords/strands-sidekick-484.html which I never would have found without someone mentioning it yesterday. They said they're publishing Sidekick twice a day to better accommodate time zones around the world. That's confusing to me, we'll see how that works out.

1D  [Gear tooth] - COG

... in today's L.A. Times xword!

Did we really need yet another sign of the apocalypse? We get it. We're doomed. Goodnight, Irene.


"I want my pink shirt back! I want my pink shirt back!"

Delightful puzzle.

Favorite movie line: "Oh my G-d, I'm surrounded by Assholes." (Spaceballs)

Frankly my Dear, I don't give a damn!

Rhett Butler (Clark Gable),  Gone With The Wind
I could have had class. I could have been a contender. I could have been somebody... instead of a bum, which is what I am.

This was a pleasure, and a remedy for my Saturday puzzle PTSD.
I think I could have solved most of today's without looking at the grid.
Fun one!

Just a note: neither cashmere
nor angora are “wool”
 They are fibers from goats and rabbits or
goats. Wool comes from sheep.
Just a perfect Monday puzzle - the theme was clever and tight. And it made me chuckle, What else could you ask for?
Good morning! Positively raced through this one, not a hitch, and not even close to my PB. I don't see how I could ever have gotten a 2:22, even on a Monday!

TIL it's not "holy cannoli" hahaha
"Bye, Felicia" got a giggle out of me

Fun and very quick puzzle today - enjoyed it thoroughly. 

My favorite movie is Arthur (the original; I'll not watch the remake), and that's probably the one that gets quoted most often here. If one of us trips on something, it's "Oh! You're a hedge," and if there's an offer to bring something back from the fridge, it often takes the form of "I'll have another... do you want another fish?"

"I love the smell of napalm in the morning."

Theme related:
"It's over, Johnny."
"Hello, Clarice."

Yes, I know Hannibal Lechter never says that in "Silence of the Lambs," but it has acquired meme status, thanks to Jim Carrey's spoof on it. And we had FAVA beans but not a nice Chianti.
Just a delight of a puzzle. Finished quickly but it was such fun. BYE FELICIA was new to me, but all the crosses got me there. Thanks to he constructors and the whole team.
What a delightful puzzle! A great way to start the week! Looking forward to more collabs by these two puzzle makers.

Dustin Hoffman's ad-libbed line (when he was almost hit by an IRL cab) in "Midnight Cowboy":   

      Hey! I'm walkin' here!
My name was in this glorious Monday puzzle.  A delight to fill in.
Is “lyes” even a word? I thought it’s always just lye, singular or plural. MW seems to agree.
The woman in the picture accompanying the Wordplay column is wearing a giant outfielder's mitt, made to fit a giant left hand, on her right hand, so my day is ruined now.

They make me buy a new outfit, and they let you in with a house dress. I don't get it.
Pay me a compliment, Melvin. I need one. Quick.

  - As Good As It Gets

"Get busy living or get busy dying." (The Shawshank Redemption)

Solving any puzzle by the great Andrea Carla Michaels is living!

Congratulations on your debut,  Dena. You and ACME together  have made for a ferocious constructing duo. 
Many thanks to both!
Great puzzle! I laughed out loud at 45 Down, "They're right at 90 degrees." Perfect Monday!
"Gentlemen! You can’t fight in here! This is the war room!”
Very fun and quick!  Just delightful!

I was reading a book on aging and it said doing crossword puzzles doesn’t help because you are just calling up words you know. I disagree.

Your thoughts?
In regards to 37D, the Trojan priest Laocoon actually called out the horse as a Greek ploy but Athena kept the Trojans from believing him and sent two sea serpents to kill him and his sons.
Quick and fun puzzle, knocked it out in 4:40

I can't imaging picking just one favorite movie quote. So many genres, so many great movies, so little time! 😁 Please indulge me: 

“Remember, Red: hope is a good thing, maybe the best of things, and no good thing ever dies.” (Shawshank Redemption)
-
"Brothers don't shake hands. Brothers gotta hug!" (Tommy Boy)
-
Westley: "You're that smart?"
Vizzini: "Let me put it this way. Have you ever heard of Plato, Aristotle, Socrates?"
Westley:  "Yes."
Vizzini: "Morons."
(Princess Bride)
-
"Listen, strange women lyin' in ponds distributin' swords is no basis for a system of government. Supreme executive power derives from a mandate from the masses, not from some farcical aquatic ceremony."  along with "Come and see the violence inherent in the system. Help! Help! I'm being repressed!" (Holy Grail)
--
 "Strange, isn't it? Each man's life touches so many other lives. And when he isn't around he leaves an awful hole, doesn't he?"
(It's a Wonderful Life)
--
".......Can you see her? I want you to picture that little girl. Now imagine she's white.” (A Time to Kll)
“Never go in against a Sicilian when death is on the line!”

Favorite movie line:
"We'll always have Paris."

Runner-up:
"I love the smell of napalm in the morning.  It smells like...victory."

Honorable mention: 
"You don't understand. I coulda had class. I coulda been a contender. I coulda been somebody, instead of a bum, which is what I am."

You'd look good in a shower curtain.
   - White Heat
Great quick puzzle!

Not original to the movie, but

"So shines a good deed in a weary world"

 - Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
Fun! Grazie!

After breezing through a nice Monday puzzle I came to "Bye Felicia". Is this one of those things that I'm gonna have to remember just for the NYT crossword? Where in a conversation can it be used, other than actually saying goodbye to a person name Felicia?
“Forget it, Jake. It’s Chinatown.”

One more late quote that dawned on me;

21 letters: 

ICOULDABEENACONTENDER

Never been in a puzzle. 

I'm done. 

...
I beat my Monday record today!! 5:11
Another ACM production! Always delighted when her name pops up, and this did not disappoint. Kudos to her collaborator too.

“It’s showtime, folks!”

 (All That Jazz)
"Soylent Green is people!"

And... a late puzzle find. A Wednesday from April 10, 2013 by Julian Lim. Theme answers in that one: 

HERESJOHNNY
ISEEDEADPEOPLE
YOUHADMEATHELLO
STELLAHEYSTELLA
ETPHONEHOME

I'm done.

...

If the original clues had last names tied to them, that really wasn't necessary.  This puzzle was easy enough to get all the them answers from the crosses.  I finished 6 seconds slower than my personal best Monday.  That's about as fast as I can read and type.

For some reason my Saturday BP is shorter than Monday's???  No idea why.  I have NEVER done a Sat puzzle in under 20 or 30 min -- let alone the 5 min mark in my Stats.  I asked the tech gurus about fixing it, but then can only wipe me out so I have to start over.  I don't want to lose my 2600  puzzels completed!

A fun, fresh puzzle to start the week.  I'm not a huge movie buff and don't have any quotes to share, but I did have a lot of fun going  through the comments, reading all your quotes and quizzing my husband to see how many he knew.  He knew a lot of them (he watches too many movies when we're off for the summer!) and really appreciated that there are a lot of Monty Python and Princess Bride fans solving crosswords.  
Thanks for the fun start to the week, Dena and Andrea, I hope you have another collaboration for us soon.

I was blazing along until the very bottom.  I never heard of the phrase at 61A nor the "Princess of Power" at 54D. Plus, FED at 62D wasn't obvious to me.

My age is showing ...

⭐️⭐️⭐️

I liked this one.  Not usually a fan of Monday puzzles, which can be pedestrian.  But this one had some pizzazz (had to check the spelling of that!), solved in 12 seconds over average.  Well done to the setters!
This was a delight and I did enjoy. Relief from the weekend challenges but just enough twists and turns to be fun. Thank you.

“There’s no crying in baseball!”
“You’re killin’ me, Smalls!”
“I’m your huckleberry.”
“My mama always said, life is like a box of chocolates…”

Bruce Wayne:  “ Alfred, this soup is cold!”
Alfred:  “It’s Vichyssoise, it’s supposed to be cold.”

This was a great puzzle. Just throwing in my two cents. :)

Having listened to She-Ra books on tape over and over again (inadvertently teaching myself how to read) as a small child, I incorrectly had Princess ADORA instead of SHERA (her alter ego) until I realized NOWAYJOSE was that right. 

Fun solve!

My favorite used-before clues from last week:

[Places to bear witness?] 
[Unlocked?]


ZOOS
BALD

@Lewis

For the Santa Tracker...there's a subscription app called ForeFlight--it's an aviation app.  Has dozens of features that  make flying easier and therefore safer.

On Christmas Eve, they get very clever with the weather part of the app.  They write in reindeer sightings, Santa being around north of the airfield, and the like.  Jingle Bell noise abatement procedures, etc.  Fun.

But that's not why I came to this part.  Is it just me, or the connection between the theme and the fill sorta loosely-goosey?  Or did I miss something deeper?
@Joe Horton - I also think the revealer was not much of a revealer.  GeezLouise, WhoaNellie, NoWayJose are very common.  Felicia less so.  (I like Get off the bus, Gus better).

@Mike
You're scaring the daylights out of us. I hope your hands are clean this time and that there's nothing even remotely to be alarmed about.  Maybe it's a setup?

@Mike

What's the difference between a croc analog?

@Josh

Yes. It’s the first time in a while when I had to go back ands change a few entries.
@Josh tried it on a Monday and my heart stood still.  Da do ron ron da do ron ron.
@Francis You made me curious, so I had to look it up. Pretty interesting: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bye,_Felicia
@Francis It even has its own Wikipedia page: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bye,_Felicia I was not aware of where it came from when Mr sister and I started using it. It just sounded funny to us.

@Beth in Greenbelt

Sorry. Didn't see Joe's comment when I posted mine.

@Beth in Greenbelt

And I didn't mean to type Mr sister, but that's pretty funny.
@Francis
I'm surprised the term "Lighten Up Francis" didn't make the cut, from Stripes.

@Francis

BYEFELICIA was new to me too, but my daughter in law said it’s pretty common in her age group

@SP

My sister and I use it too. I'm 60 and she's 55. But we probably learned it from one of her kids.

@Beth in Greenbelt

Well.....thanks, I guess.
I didn't get  it, and now I am pretty sure this is not worth knowing or remembering.

The quote OUR family likes best:
"We don't need no stinkin' [badges....but insert anything here!]!!!"
@Mean Old Lady it’s exactly the same as every other theme answer in the grid. Just newer.

@Mean Old Lady

"not worth knowing or remembering" 

And The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is? GEEZ LOUISE! 

You never know from whence a true gem of a quote might come. I have been known to use BYE, FELICIA -- and a rendition of not needing "stinkin' badges". Just maybe not together!

@Beth in Greenbelt

GEEZLOUISE was literally the clue for 93A in yesterday's puzzle. So I think the conspiracy is larger than you realize. ;-)

JMF,

I was shocked to discover that "holy kamoley"
(yes, with a k) and HOLY [Camoly!] 
seem to predate "holy cannoli."

I also leave the gun.
@JMF   And I've always said "holy moly" which led me to making the pun joke "What is that Mexican sauce made using holy water? Holy mole?"

@JMF

And I thought it was holy guacamole!

@JMF
Thanks!
I will put the etymology info in my “TIL” category! 
And I’ll share the word joke with a friend who loves mole. lol!

@JMF

always "holy gamoley" for me.

@Whoa Nellie
And isn’t it “Felisha”?

@Whoa Nellie,

At least it wasn’t WOAH!

@NYC Traveler

That was my thought, too! After giving some serious side-eye to that Y...

@OboeSteph

I knew Papa Hemingway but not Papa Haydn.

@OboeSteph

It's weird...reading the lyrics, I couldn't help but set it to music.

@OboeSteph

I'm with @Beth in Greenbelt on this one. I'm rather surprised how many commenters had not heard the PAPA Hemingway moniker! Picture him circa Old Man and the Sea, all round face and white beard...
I was somewhat surprised that our columnist was unaware of PAPA for both Haydn and Hemingway.
@Mark

@Mark
I know Phrygian, Ionian, etc., to be of Ancient Greek origins. How do you figure a French hat?
@Jerry I guess like me the clue was read as “Persian” … the mind plays tricks given recent events
@Jerry think “liberty cap” as in the French Revolution
@ https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolism_in_the_French_Revolution#Liberty_cap
@Patricia Henry Sadly they screwed up the original freedman’s cap and went with the Phrygian. Brutus’ ides of March coin has the right one. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ides_of_March_coin

@Patricia Henry
Thank you, consider me better educated now.

@Whoa Nellie
Some of us LOVE OREOS!  Although the real thing is much better than than the xword variety, of course!

@john ezra

Loved your comments on "Taxi Driver".  I, too, felt immersed in sewage about 15 minutes into the film, which of course was such masterful cinematography.

And, DeNiro was spectacular.  At certain points you could believe he was a basically good guy, with enough on the ball to get a date with Sybil Sheppard.   

Then at other points you can't believe how every little thing he does just oozes intimidation...

I've seen it more than once,  but it's not a movie I gravitate toward rewatching.
@Wes Was just about to make the same post! A perfect line, perfectly delivered.

@Larry

It became a common thing after Ice Cube created it!

@Andrzej
It's not just you. Puzzle creators choose AHH or AaH based on what they need to make the fill work. When I'm faced with the choice, I just fill in the first A and the last H, then wait for the cross to tell me what the middle letter needs to be. (That's what I did tonight).

@Grumpy

I do and did that, too.

@Andrzej

@Andrzej

@Andrzej

Brands are artificial constructs that mean nothing by themselves. They are used to exploit people, making them make irrational decisions.

I once had an Audi. Some of its parts were exactly the same as in the much more plebeian VW. They were made in the same factory. They were just branded with a different logo. The "Audi" part cost 3 times as much as the - exactly same - VW part.

My students eat cheap food, because they can't afford better, yet they buy Balenciaga backpacks because they have been conditioned to perceive their self-worth via the brands of the products they are seen with.

I could go on like this for days.

Also, I know enough marketing people to appreciate what a load of bee ess brand building is.

@Andrzej

I came a generation ahead of you, and I don't think we were inundated by the six-pack-abs, arms-like-thighs males like you were.  I think I would have hated that.

We were more inclined towards the cowboy type...the strong, silent type which Clint Eastwood, IMO, has probably had the last, unimproveable word.

And I kind of rejected them, gravitating towards the funny guys, the Dick Van Dykes and the Bob Newharts, the Smothers Brothers.  Entertainers. Johnny Carson (although I cringe almost every time I see a clip from his shows).  

This all probably helps explain why I am so out of phase with the masculinity culture we have now.

Yeah, I got one.  It almost hurts to say that this one got me, but it *really* got me.

"Unforgiven":  the "kid" of the group has killed someone for hire, and is now realizing what that actually means.  He's talking to the veteran killer, Clint Eastwood, trying to easy his conscience:

"Well, I guess he had it coming."

"We all got it coming, kid.", was Eastwood's response, in the best Eastwood monotone ever.

That still gives me chills.
